item.dc:title: Cs2CO3‐I2 Promoted Efficient Synthesis of Flavones and Flavanones: Total Synthesis of Narengenin and Apigenin

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Metal‐Free Direct Synthesis of Secondary Amides and Nitriles Using O‐(2‐Pyrimidinyl)‐N‐Boc Hydroxylamine
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
We explored the first application of the novel O‐(2‐pyrimidinyl)‐N‐Boc hydroxylamine reagent for the direct synthesis of secondary amides and nitriles from ketones and aldehydes via the Beckmann rearrangement. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that this reagent is more stable than similar alternatives. This protocol offers notable advantages: it is operationally simple, mild, metal‐free, conducted in open air, scalable, operates at ambient temperature, high yields, and demonstrates good functional group tolerance.
Abstract A novel hydroxylamine‐derived aminating agent, O‐(2‐pyrimidinyl)‐N‐Boc hydroxylamine (PymONHBoc), has been designed and synthesized, from readily available 2‐chloropyrimidine. This reagent demonstrates superior shelf stability and ease of handling compared to other hydroxylamine‐derived reagents. Here, we present a metal‐free method for the direct conversion of ketones and aldehydes into sec‐amides and nitriles using PymONHBoc as the aminating agent. This method efficiently converts a wide range of aliphatic and aromatic carbonyl compounds into the corresponding amides and nitriles with good to excellent yields under ambient conditions. The use of PymONHBoc is advantageous, as it facilitates the in situ generation of the activated oxime intermediate, concomitantly producing a non‐interfering byproduct.
item.content:encoded:
We explored the first application of the novel O-(2-pyrimidinyl)-N-Boc hydroxylamine reagent for the direct synthesis of secondary amides and nitriles from ketones and aldehydes via the Beckmann rearrangement. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that this reagent is more stable than similar alternatives. This protocol offers notable advantages: it is operationally simple, mild, metal-free, conducted in open air, scalable, operates at ambient temperature, high yields, and demonstrates good functional group tolerance.


Abstract

A novel hydroxylamine-derived aminating agent, O-(2-pyrimidinyl)-N-Boc hydroxylamine (PymONHBoc), has been designed and synthesized, from readily available 2-chloropyrimidine. This reagent demonstrates superior shelf stability and ease of handling compared to other hydroxylamine-derived reagents. Here, we present a metal-free method for the direct conversion of ketones and aldehydes into sec-amides and nitriles using PymONHBoc as the aminating agent. This method efficiently converts a wide range of aliphatic and aromatic carbonyl compounds into the corresponding amides and nitriles with good to excellent yields under ambient conditions. The use of PymONHBoc is advantageous, as it facilitates the in situ generation of the activated oxime intermediate, concomitantly producing a non-interfering byproduct.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Greening the Synthesis of 2,3‐Dihydrobenzofuran Selenides: I2/TBHP‐Promoted Selenocyclization of 2‐Allylphenols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An alternative and green method to produce 2‐[(organoselanyl)methyl]‐2,3‐dihydrobenzofurans promoted by the I2/TBHP oxidant system was developed. The reactions occur in only one minute in the presence of different 2‐allylphenols and diorganyl diselenides at room temperature using 10 mol % I2 and 0.30 mmol of TBHP in the absence of solvent to obtain fifteen compounds in yields up to 93 %.
Abstract In this work we describe the synthesis of selenium‐containing dihydrobenzofurans through the selenocyclization reaction of 2‐allylphenols. The reaction procedure uses only an I2/TBHP oxidant system at room temperature, enabling an efficient synthesis of 2‐[(organoselanyl)methyl]‐2,3‐dihydrobenzofurans. The products are formed immediately after the addition of the oxidant system in a mixture of 2‐allylphenol and diorganyl diselenide, in the absence of solvent, at mild experimental conditions. Furthermore, control experiments were carried out, including 77Se NMR analyses to identify intermediates, which contributed to the elucidation of the reaction mechanism.
item.content:encoded:
An alternative and green method to produce 2-[(organoselanyl)methyl]-2,3-dihydrobenzofurans promoted by the I2/TBHP oxidant system was developed. The reactions occur in only one minute in the presence of different 2-allylphenols and diorganyl diselenides at room temperature using 10 mol % I2 and 0.30 mmol of TBHP in the absence of solvent to obtain fifteen compounds in yields up to 93 %.


Abstract

In this work we describe the synthesis of selenium-containing dihydrobenzofurans through the selenocyclization reaction of 2-allylphenols. The reaction procedure uses only an I2/TBHP oxidant system at room temperature, enabling an efficient synthesis of 2-[(organoselanyl)methyl]-2,3-dihydrobenzofurans. The products are formed immediately after the addition of the oxidant system in a mixture of 2-allylphenol and diorganyl diselenide, in the absence of solvent, at mild experimental conditions. Furthermore, control experiments were carried out, including 77Se NMR analyses to identify intermediates, which contributed to the elucidation of the reaction mechanism.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Theoretical Investigation on the Copper‐Catalyzed anti‐Selective 1,2‐Silylboration of Internal Alkynes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The mechanism of a copper‐catalyzed regio‐ and anti‐selective 1,2‐silylboration of internal alkynes was theoretically studied to understand the reaction pathway and the origin of selectivity. The proposed overall reaction pathway involves the syn‐to‐anti isomerization via an anionic allenic transition state stabilized by the conjugation with the benzene ring. The anti‐selectivity is determined at the borylation step and controlled by the steric effect of the silyl group introduced on the alkyne carbon. The computational results obtained in this study are highly informative for the development of new catalytic transformations involving syn/anti‐isomerization processes.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Solvent‐Directed Regioselective Cascade Reaction with Diazo Compounds
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A green, efficient and highly regioselective synthesis of pyrazoles and their derivatives from the combination of two different diazo compounds to afford N‐substituted using CF3CH2OTf as reaction medium was developed, without any catalysts.
Abstract A tandem system comprising cyclization reaction of diazo compound and cross‐coupling of the other one has been developed. This provides facile access to pyrazoles and there derivatives with high levels of regioselectivity in moderate to good yields. This process uniquely utilizes CF3CH2OTf both as a solvent and a catalyst under mild conditions. Mechanistic studies provide insights into the intricate sequence involved in the formation of pyrazoles and further selective cross‐coupling with another diazo compound.
item.content:encoded:
A green, efficient and highly regioselective synthesis of pyrazoles and their derivatives from the combination of two different diazo compounds to afford N-substituted using CF3CH2OTf as reaction medium was developed, without any catalysts.


Abstract

A tandem system comprising cyclization reaction of diazo compound and cross-coupling of the other one has been developed. This provides facile access to pyrazoles and there derivatives with high levels of regioselectivity in moderate to good yields. This process uniquely utilizes CF3CH2OTf both as a solvent and a catalyst under mild conditions. Mechanistic studies provide insights into the intricate sequence involved in the formation of pyrazoles and further selective cross-coupling with another diazo compound.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Construction of Dibenzo[a,c]Carbazoles through Oxidative Diels‐Alder Reaction of 2‐Phenyl‐1H‐Indoles and Benzynes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
We have described the construction of dibenzo[a,c]carbazoles via the oxidative [4+2] Diels‐Alder cycloaddition reaction of 2‐phenyl‐1H‐indoles with benzynes. The features of this method include the use of readily available raw materials, it being free of transition‐metal‐catalyst, the use of molecular oxygen as the oxidant, and convenient method for the preparation of π‐extended polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.
Abstract We present here a convenient synthesis of the dibenzo[a,c]carbazoles via oxidative [4+2] Diels‐Alder cycloaddition of 2‐phenyl‐1H‐indoles with benzynes. The features of this protocol include the use of readily available raw materials, molecular oxygen as the oxidant, it being free of transition‐metal‐catalyst, and convenient method for the preparation of π‐extended dibenzo[a,c]carbazoles.
item.content:encoded:
We have described the construction of dibenzo[a,c]carbazoles via the oxidative [4+2] Diels-Alder cycloaddition reaction of 2-phenyl-1H-indoles with benzynes. The features of this method include the use of readily available raw materials, it being free of transition-metal-catalyst, the use of molecular oxygen as the oxidant, and convenient method for the preparation of π-extended polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.


Abstract

We present here a convenient synthesis of the dibenzo[a,c]carbazoles via oxidative [4+2] Diels-Alder cycloaddition of 2-phenyl-1H-indoles with benzynes. The features of this protocol include the use of readily available raw materials, molecular oxygen as the oxidant, it being free of transition-metal-catalyst, and convenient method for the preparation of π-extended dibenzo[a,c]carbazoles.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Versatile Synthesis of Linalool‐Derived Compounds via Catalytic Epoxidation and Ring Opening
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: This study focuses on the selective epoxidation of linalool to produce linalool epoxide, a valuable intermediate for the synthesis of novel linalool‐derived compounds. A robust and non‐noble cobalt catalyst was employed to achieve high yields of linalool epoxide under mild reaction conditions. The catalytic system displayed remarkable efficiency and reusability, providing a platform for exploring different feedstock, including rosewood oil, to demonstrate its versatility in raw feedstock valorization. Further functionalization of linalool‐derived molecules was achieved through regioselective ring‐opening reactions, yielding novel ethers with potential applications in the fine chemical industry. In summary, this study presents a comprehensive approach to the sustainable synthesis of linalool‐derived compounds, displaying the versatility of the catalytic system and providing a basis for the development of novel fine organic compounds with potential industrial applications.

Further functionalization of linalool-derived molecules was achieved through regioselective ring-opening reactions, yielding novel ethers with potential applications in the fine chemical industry. In summary, this study presents a comprehensive approach to the sustainable synthesis of linalool-derived compounds, displaying the versatility of the catalytic system and providing a basis for the development of novel fine organic compounds with potential industrial applications.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Unraveling Phenanthrenoid Dimerization in Juncus acutus: A DFT‐guided Exploration of Radical‐Coupling Reaction Mechanisms
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Juncus acutus is a plant found near ponds and brackish marshes, producing secondary metabolites like phenanthrenoid dimers with antibacterial, antioxidant, and anti‐inflammatory activities. Despite this, little is known about the detailed mechanisms behind their dimerization reactions. In this study, we used Density Functional Theory to explore the reaction mechanisms of phenanthrene and dihydrophenanthrene species in radical coupling, both in gas‐phase and solution. The dimerization reactions, initiated by the OH radical, result in the formation of two phenanthrenoid dimers (homodimer and heterodimer). The OH radical abstracts a hydrogen atom from the hydroxyl group, leading to the formation of radicals and water. Our analysis of electronic spin density highlighted the preferred reactive sites that drive regioselective dimer formation. Furthermore, the study identifies a triplet π‐π stacked intermediate preceding the diketone formation on the singlet potential energy surface, revealing a two‐state reactivity mechanism. The diketone dimers are then converted via a water‐mediated keto‐enol tautomerization into their dienolic forms, completing the reaction pathway. This work offers insights into the complex dimerization processes of phenanthrenoids in nature, using computational methods to shed light on poorly understood molecular mechanisms in plant organisms.

Despite this, little is known about the detailed mechanisms behind their dimerization reactions. In this study, we used Density Functional Theory to explore the reaction mechanisms of phenanthrene and dihydrophenanthrene species in radical coupling, both in gas-phase and solution. The dimerization reactions, initiated by the OH radical, result in the formation of two phenanthrenoid dimers (homodimer and heterodimer). The OH radical abstracts a hydrogen atom from the hydroxyl group, leading to the formation of radicals and water. Our analysis of electronic spin density highlighted the preferred reactive sites that drive regioselective dimer formation. Furthermore, the study identifies a triplet π-π stacked intermediate preceding the diketone formation on the singlet potential energy surface, revealing a two-state reactivity mechanism. The diketone dimers are then converted via a water-mediated keto-enol tautomerization into their dienolic forms, completing the reaction pathway. This work offers insights into the complex dimerization processes of phenanthrenoids in nature, using computational methods to shed light on poorly understood molecular mechanisms in plant organisms.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Multigram Synthesis of 3‐Azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane Derivatives Including Bicyclic Thalidomide Analogs
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: An efficient approach to the multigram synthesis of 3‐azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptanes is described. The method relied on the intramolecular imide formation in the properly 1,3‐functionalized cyclobutane derivative. In turn, the latter compound was obtained via the diastereoselective Strecker reaction of readily accessible 3‐oxo­cyclobutanecarboxylate. The resulting synthetic intermediate – 1‐amino‐3‐azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane‐2,4‐dione – was used to synthe­size several monoprotected bicyclic diamines valuable as building blocks for medicinal chemistry, as well as a series of bridged analogs of Thalidomide, a known anticancer drug and a component of proteolysis‐targeting chimeras (PROTACs).
item.content:encoded: An efficient approach to the multigram synthesis of 3-azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptanes is described. The method relied on the intramolecular imide formation in the properly 1,3-functionalized cyclobutane derivative. In turn, the latter compound was obtained via the diastereoselective Strecker reaction of readily accessible 3-oxo­cyclobutanecarboxylate. The resulting synthetic intermediate – 1-amino-3-azabicyclo[3.1.1]heptane-2,4-dione – was used to synthe­size several monoprotected bicyclic diamines valuable as building blocks for medicinal chemistry, as well as a series of bridged analogs of Thalidomide, a known anticancer drug and a component of proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs).

item.title: Samarium Diiodide/Samarium‐Mediated Deoxygenative Hydroborylation of Aldehydes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A samarium diiodide/samarium‐mediated direct deoxygenative hydroborylation of aldehydes with hydroborate ester has been reported. In this method, unactivated aldehydes and hydroborate ester have been employed as starting materials for the synthesis of primary alkyl borate esters. Broad substrate scope and excellent functional group tolerance has been demonstrated that this is a robust method for deoxygenative hydroborylation of aldehydes.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in the Direct N–C(sp2) Nitrone Synthesis from Oxime
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Nitrones are pivotal in organic chemistry, especially for the synthesis of natural and biologically active compounds via 1,3‐dipolar cycloadditions and Kinugasa reactions. Although numerous methods have been reported for the synthesis of nitrones with an sp3 carbon connected to a nitrogen atom, the development of nitrones with an sp2 carbon linkage, including N‐vinyl, N‐aryl, and N‐alkoxycarbonyl nitrones, remains relatively underexplored. This review summarizes the current research trends and methodologies for the direct synthesis of nitrones, in which an sp2 carbon is directly bonded to a nitrogen atom, beginning with oximes.
